original_text: We shall establish the variational format in the space–time domain S=defΩ×I, for given spatial domain Ω and time domain I=(0,T), for a quite broad class of problems involving a first order time-derivative. In particular, the coupled problem of consolidation of geomaterials falls within this class. Another interesting application is the problem of dynamics, rewritten in first-order form, i.e. through a Hamiltonian description. It is of considerable interest to note from the outset that, due to the forward transport of information in time, it is always possible to consider a set of finite time intervals, whereby the solution at the end of any such interval will act as the initial data for the next one. To this end, we introduce a partition 0=t0<t1<⋯<tN=T of the considered time domain I=(0,T) into time-intervals In=(tn−1,tn) of length Δtn=tn−tn−1.11The abbreviated notation Δt=Δtn will be used henceforth for the current time step associated with In. Hence, we define space–time slabs Sn=defΩ×In such that the space–time domain can be given as S=defΩ×I=S1∪S2⋯∪Sn.
original_translation: Estableceremos el formato variacional en el dominio espacio–temporal S=defΩ×I, para un dominio espacial Ω dado y un dominio temporal I=(0,T), para una amplia clase de problemas que involucran una derivada temporal de primer orden. En particular, el problema acoplado de consolidación de geomateriales entra en esta categoría. Otra aplicación interesante es el problema de la dinámica, reescrito en forma de primer orden, es decir, a través de una descripción hamiltoniana. Es de gran interés notar desde el principio que, debido al transporte hacia adelante de la información en el tiempo, siempre es posible considerar un conjunto de intervalos de tiempo finitos, donde la solución al final de cada intervalo actuará como los datos iniciales para el siguiente. Con este fin, introducimos una partición 0=t0<t1<⋯<tN=T del dominio de tiempo considerado I=(0,T) en intervalos de tiempo In=(tn−1,tn) de longitud Δtn=tn−tn−1. La notación abreviada Δt=Δtn se utilizará de ahora en adelante para el paso de tiempo actual asociado con In. Por lo tanto, definimos láminas espacio-temporales Sn=defΩ×In de tal manera que el dominio espacio-temporal pueda ser dado como S=defΩ×I=S1∪S2⋯∪Sn.
original_sentences: We shall establish the variational format in the space–time domain S=defΩ×I, for given spatial domain Ω and time domain I=(0,T), for a quite broad class of problems involving a first order time-derivative.
In particular, the coupled problem of consolidation of geomaterials falls within this class.
Another interesting application is the problem of dynamics, rewritten in first-order form, i.e. through a Hamiltonian description.

It is of considerable interest to note from the outset that, due to the forward transport of information in time, it is always possible to consider a set of finite time intervals, whereby the solution at the end of any such interval will act as the initial data for the next one.

To this end, we introduce a partition 0=t0<t1<⋯<tN=T of the considered time domain I=(0,T) into time-intervals In=(tn−1,tn) of length Δtn=tn−tn−1.11The abbreviated notation Δt=Δtn will be used henceforth for the current time step associated with In.
Hence, we define space–time slabs Sn=defΩ×In such that the space–time domain can be given as S=defΩ×I=S1∪S2⋯∪Sn.

Es de gran interés notar desde el principio que, debido al transporte hacia adelante de la información en el tiempo, siempre es posible considerar un conjunto de intervalos de tiempo finitos, donde la solución al final de cada intervalo actuará como los datos iniciales para el siguiente. Con este fin, introducimos una partición 0=t0

original_annotated_sentences:
We shall establish the variational format in the space–time domain S=defΩ×I, for given spatial domain Ω and
time domain I=(0,T)
, for a quite broad class of problems involving a first order time-derivative.
In particular, the coupled problem of consolidation of geomaterials falls within this class.
Another interesting application is the problem of dynamics, rewritten in first-order form, i.e. through a Hamiltonian description.

It is of considerable interest to note from the outset that, due to the forward transport of information in time, it is always possible to consider a set of finite time intervals, whereby the solution at the end of any such interval will act as the initial data for the next one.

To this end, we introduce a partition 0=t0time domain I=(0,T)
into time-intervals In=(tn−1,tn) of length Δtn=tn−tn−1.11The abbreviated notation Δt=Δtn will be used henceforth for the current time step associated with In.
Hence, we define space–time slabs Sn=defΩ×In such that the space–time domain can be given as S=defΩ×I=S1∪S2⋯∪Sn.
